resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:37708156</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-I7A</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Illinois. Commission on State Government.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Minutes, staff memoranda, and agenda papers, 1965-1967.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>File includes Commission on State Government regular meeting minutes (November 5, 1965 - November 29, 1966) and research committee minutes (December 8, 1965 - May 17, 1966).  Commission research staff memoranda discuss state government organization, fiscal management, and general policies.  Typical topics include labor law administration; public welfare and health services; personnel policy; intergovernmental relations; inheritance tax administration; study of state executive officers; executive code departments (e.g., Aeronautics; Conservation; Financial Institutions; Labor; Mental Health; Public Health); Human Relations Commission; Liquor Control Commission; Illinois Commerce Commission; and Illinois Veterans' Commission.  Agenda papers were drawn largely from staff memoranda and cover the same subjects.  Besides Division of Waterways, Northern Illinois University, and University of Illinois reports, the file includes the commission's report to the Governor and General Assembly accompanied by correspondence on the commission report to the chairman from dissenting commission members. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Illinois State Archive</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Minutes, staff memoranda, and agenda papers, 1965-1967.
resource.abstract: File includes Commission on State Government regular meeting minutes (November 5, 1965 - November 29, 1966) and research committee minutes (December 8, 1965 - May 17, 1966).  Commission research staff memoranda discuss state government organization, fiscal management, and general policies.  Typical topics include labor law administration; public welfare and health services; personnel policy; intergovernmental relations; inheritance tax administration; study of state executive officers; executive code departments (e.g., Aeronautics; Conservation; Financial Institutions; Labor; Mental Health; Public Health); Human Relations Commission; Liquor Control Commission; Illinois Commerce Commission; and Illinois Veterans' Commission.  Agenda papers were drawn largely from staff memoranda and cover the same subjects.  Besides Division of Waterways, Northern Illinois University, and University of Illinois reports, the file includes the commission's report to the Governor and General Assembly accompanied by correspondence on the commission report to the chairman from dissenting commission members.
resource.displayEntry: Illinois. Commission on State Government. Minutes, staff memoranda, and agenda papers, 1965-1967.

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:37002358</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-I7A</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Illinois Commission on Human Relations.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Minutes of Commission meetings, October 1, 1943-February 20, 1963.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Minutes of regular and special Commission meetings concern racial conditions in Illinois, especially in schools or black neighborhoods, and discrimination experienced by other minority groups. Nearly all major race incidents in Illinois between 1943 and 1963 were covered by Commission representatives who reported on them at Commission meetings. Other discussions concern Governor's 1949 order banning racial segregation in Illinois National Guard, investigations by Broyles Commission, U.S. Supreme Court cases dealing with racism, urban riots and racial problems during World War II in which Commission became involved. School issues occur frequently in Commission minutes, including segregation patterns of school districts, lack of participation by Black schools in state tournaments, implementation of state law that authorized teaching of Black history in public schools, legislative amendments to strengthen laws that forbade discrimination in public schools and state monies spent to transport children to all-white private schools. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Illinois State Archive</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Minutes of Commission meetings, October 1, 1943-February 20, 1963.
resource.abstract: Minutes of regular and special Commission meetings concern racial conditions in Illinois, especially in schools or black neighborhoods, and discrimination experienced by other minority groups. Nearly all major race incidents in Illinois between 1943 and 1963 were covered by Commission representatives who reported on them at Commission meetings. Other discussions concern Governor's 1949 order banning racial segregation in Illinois National Guard, investigations by Broyles Commission, U.S. Supreme Court cases dealing with racism, urban riots and racial problems during World War II in which Commission became involved. School issues occur frequently in Commission minutes, including segregation patterns of school districts, lack of participation by Black schools in state tournaments, implementation of state law that authorized teaching of Black history in public schools, legislative amendments to strengthen laws that forbade discrimination in public schools and state monies spent to transport children to all-white private schools.
resource.displayEntry: Illinois Commission on Human Relations. Minutes of Commission meetings, October 1, 1943-February 20, 1963.

resourceRelations.content: Illinois Commission on Human Relations. Minutes of Commission meetings, October 1, 1943-February 20, 1963.

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:36239621</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-I7A</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Illinois. Office of the Superintendent of Public Instruction.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Administrative records for the boards of trustees of state colleges and universities, 1962-1968.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Files include administrative records concerning colleges and universities for which the Superintendent served on the board of trustees.  These institutions include Southern Illinois University; Eastern Illinois University; Northern Illinois University; University of Illinois; Western Illinois University; Illinois State University; Northeastern Illinois State University; and Chicago State College. Records include internal budgets; financial statements; business manager reports; minutes; feasibility studies; committee reports; progress reports; newspaper clippings; complaints; and related correspondence.  Subjects include faculty salaries and hiring; enrollment; curriculum; state and federal legislation; university housing; construction projects; admissions policy; accreditation; grant funding; tuition and fees; athletic programs; internal organization; parking regulations; and department head appointments. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Illinois State Archive</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Administrative records for the boards of trustees of state colleges and universities, 1962-1968.
resource.abstract: Files include administrative records concerning colleges and universities for which the Superintendent served on the board of trustees.  These institutions include Southern Illinois University; Eastern Illinois University; Northern Illinois University; University of Illinois; Western Illinois University; Illinois State University; Northeastern Illinois State University; and Chicago State College. Records include internal budgets; financial statements; business manager reports; minutes; feasibility studies; committee reports; progress reports; newspaper clippings; complaints; and related correspondence.  Subjects include faculty salaries and hiring; enrollment; curriculum; state and federal legislation; university housing; construction projects; admissions policy; accreditation; grant funding; tuition and fees; athletic programs; internal organization; parking regulations; and department head appointments.
resource.displayEntry: Illinois. Office of the Superintendent of Public Instruction. Administrative records for the boards of trustees of state colleges and universities, 1962-1968.

			 <subarea>Maureen and Mike Mansfield Library</subarea>

			 Collections</subarea>
                     </corpname>
                     <address>
                        <addressline>The University of Montana-Missoula </addressline>
                        <addressline>Missoula, MT 59812</addressline>
                        <addressline>406-243-2053</addressline>
                        <addressline>http://www.lib.umt.edu/asc</addressline>
                        <addressline>library.archives@umontana.edu</addressline>
                     </address>
                  </repository>
                  <unitid>Mss
		  752</unitid>
                  <origination>
                     <persname>Bowers,
			 Richard C. (Richard Charles), 1927-1996 </persname>
                  </origination>
                  <unittitle>Richard C. Bowers
		  scrapbooks </unittitle>
                  <unitdate>1973-1980</unitdate>
                  <physdesc>
                     <extent>12 volumes</extent>
                  </physdesc>
                  <abstract>The collection consists of twelve
		  scrapbooks containing newspaper clippings about Richard C. Bowers and The
		  University of Montana-Missoula, with occasional mention of his wife, Florence
		  Bowers. The scrapbooks begin in 1973 when Richard Bowers was Vice President of
		  Academic Affairs at Northern Illinois University and continue through his
		  hiring at The University of Montana in 1974 and into 1980, the year before his
		  term as President of The University of Montana ended.</abstract>
                  <langmaterial>Materials are in <language>English</language>
                  </langmaterial>
               </did>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Richard C. Bowers  scrapbooks 1973-1980
resource.abstract: The collection consists of twelve  scrapbooks containing newspaper clippings about Richard C. Bowers and The  University of Montana-Missoula, with occasional mention of his wife, Florence  Bowers. The scrapbooks begin in 1973 when Richard Bowers was Vice President of  Academic Affairs at Northern Illinois University and continue through his  hiring at The University of Montana in 1974 and into 1980, the year before his  term as President of The University of Montana ended.

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:28410183</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-UIU</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>American Association of University Professors. Illinois Conference.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Polzin, Donald E., 1930-</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Archives, 1958-1980.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Subject files of president Donald Polzin and other conference officers, including correspondence, reports, clippings, articles, newsletters, photos, minutes, membership mailing lists, and other materials. Topics include academic freedom and tenure, loyalty oaths, teacher's unions, strikes, the Staughton Lynd case, campus unrest, unionization and collective bargaining, the periodical Illinois Academe, Northern Illinois University Chapter of the AAUP, and the Clabaugh Act, which served to keep Communist speakers off the campuses of University of Illinois between 1947 and 1968. Correspondents include AAUP members, state politicians and educators, lawyers, and Arthur J. Dipden, Victor Stone, and Allen D. Weaver. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>University of Illinois at Urbana Champaign</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Archives, 1958-1980.
resource.abstract: Subject files of president Donald Polzin and other conference officers, including correspondence, reports, clippings, articles, newsletters, photos, minutes, membership mailing lists, and other materials. Topics include academic freedom and tenure, loyalty oaths, teacher's unions, strikes, the Staughton Lynd case, campus unrest, unionization and collective bargaining, the periodical Illinois Academe, Northern Illinois University Chapter of the AAUP, and the Clabaugh Act, which served to keep Communist speakers off the campuses of University of Illinois between 1947 and 1968. Correspondents include AAUP members, state politicians and educators, lawyers, and Arthur J. Dipden, Victor Stone, and Allen D. Weaver.
resource.displayEntry: American Association of University Professors. Illinois Conference. Archives, 1958-1980.

resource.title: Horace Mann Bond Papers, 1830-1979 1926-1972
resource.abstract: Educator, sociologist, scholar, and author. Includes personal and professional correspondence; administrative and teaching records; research data; manuscripts of published and unpublished speeches, articles and books; photographs; and Bond family papers, especially those of Horace Bond's father, James Bond. Fully represented are Bond's two major interests: black education, especially its history and sociological aspects, and Africa, particularly as related to educational and political conditions. Correspondents include many notable African American educators, Africanists, activists, authors and others, such as Albert C. Barnes, Claude A. Barnett, Mary McLeod Bethune, Arna Bontemps, Ralph Bunch, Rufus Clement, J.G. St. Clair Drake, W.E.B. Du Bois, Edwin Embree, John Hope Franklin, E. Franklin Frazier, W.C. Handy, Thurgood Marshall, Benjamin E. Mays, Kwame Nkrumah, Robert Ezra Park, A. Phillip Randolph, Lawrence P. Reddick, A.A. Schomburg, George Shepperson, Carter Woodson and Monroe Work.

nameEntries.original: Special Collections and University Archives, UMass Amherst Libraries

resource.title: J. B. Matthews Papers, 1862-1986 and undated
resource.abstract: J. B. Matthews (1894-1966) was a Methodist missionary, college professor, author, lecturer, and prominent conservative spokesman. Collection consists of correspondence, memoranda, statements, speeches, reprints, clippings, broadsides, newsletters, press releases, petitions, and other printed material, chiefly 1930-1969. The principal focus of the collection relates to the work and research of Matthews and his associates in the area of anti-communism, particularly in connection with Matthews' role as Director of Research for the Special Committee on Un-American Activities of the U.S. House of Representatives (1938-1945), Executive Director of the Permanent Subcommittee on Government Operations of the U.S. Senate (1953), and a consultant for John A. Clements Associates. Many of the organizations, newspapers, periodicals, and persons represented in the collection have various leftist, socialist, communist, radical, or pacifist (especially anti-Vietnam War) connections.Individuals represented in the files include Ralph Abernathy, Bella Abzug, Roy Cohn, John Foster Dulles, Dwight D. Eisenhower, Michael Harrington, Alger Hiss, J. Edgar Hoover, Jesse Jackson, John F. Kennedy, Martin Luther King, Coretta Scott King, Joseph Lash, Joseph McCarthy, Carl McIntire, Benjamin Mandel, Richard Nixon, Aristotle Onassis, Lee Harvey Oswald, Linus Pauling, Drew Pearson, Eleanor Roosevelt, and Louis Untermeyer.
resource.displayEntry: J. B. Matthews Papers, 1862-1986 and undated
